Normal Forms 12 2NF and functional dependencies â€¢ Letâ€™s look at these two dependencies: â€¢ {Legi, Nr} -> {Name, Semester} â€¢ {Legi} -> {Name, Semester} â€¢ They state the following: â€¢ Legi determines the Name and the Semester â€¢ By adding {Legi, Nr} -> {Name, Semester}, we need to map every pair {Legi, Nr} to a pair {Name, Semester} when it is sufficient to map them to {Legi} alone â€¢ This is an indication that these two dependencies in a single relation are going to lead to redundancy in {Name, Semester} since they will have to be repeated for every combination of {Legi, Nr} â€¢ However, we need {Legi, Nr} since that is exactly the relationship that the table is meant to capture â€¢ The conclusion is that {Name, Semester} have nothing to do in that table â€¦ Normal Forms 13 2NF: Second Normal Form â€¢ {R, FD} is in 2NF iff. every non-key attribute is minimally dependent on every key. â€¢ minimally dependent: No attribute dependents on part of a key. â€¢ The example on the right is not in 2NF because of the following FD: â€¢ {Legi} -> {Name, Semester} Normal Forms 14 2NF: Second Normal Form â€¢ Problem for relations that are not in 2NF: â€¢ Insert Anomaly: Student who attend no lectures. â€¢ Update Anomaly: Increase Carnap Semester by 1. â€¢ Delete Anomaly: Fichte drops his last course. â€¢ All these can lead to redundant / inconsistent updates of the relations. Normal Forms 38 BCNF: understanding it â€¢ What happens if we actually have one table for professor and another one for room? Assume we want to enforce a 1:1 cardinality between the two â€¢ Professor: {PersNr,Name, Level,City, Street, Canton} â€¢ Room: {RoomNr, size, telephone, department, â€¦} â€¢ Does it make sense to add another relation Has_Office: {PersNr,RoomNr}? â€¢ If we do not add it, we do not map professors to offices â€¢ If we add it, we can proceed as explained to make it BCNF â€¢ However, there is certain degree of redundancy: one of the two attributes is repeated as it appears in its own relation and in the one making the connection. â€¢ The 1:1 cardinality allows us to merge the Has_Office relation with either the Professor relation or the Room relation, removing the need to have a separate table.
